captions.text:
Every day the world consumes 300 tones of
caffeine -- enough for one cup of coffee for
every man, woman and child.

The world's largest buyer of coffee, the US,
has to import nearly all of this as the coffee

trees from which caffeine is harvested will
only grow at commercial levels between the

tropic of cancer and the tropic of capricorn
in an area called the coffee belt. Only a
single state, Hawaii, is within the belt.

However, the United States is only the largest
buyer because it's so populous. The most enthusiastic

coffee drinkers per capita are, in increasing
order, the Netherlands, Denmark, Iceland,

Norway and, the world champions, Finland,
where they drink three times as much coffee

a day as the average American. All of these
countries are outside of the coffee belt and
must import 100% of their caffeine supply.

To get this caffeine, first bees must pollinate
the flowers of a coffee tree and these flowers

develop into bright red berries. Unlike more
cooperative domesticated plants, the coffee

tree does not ripen all its berries at the
same time so they need to be hand picked and
sorted.

Once picked, the coffee bean is removed from
inside the berry. This young seedling of the

tree is then dried, heated, ground and submersed
in boiling water to get out the precious,

precious caffeine. It takes about 40 coffee
beans to make one shot of espresso.

But why is caffeine in the coffee beans in
the first place? It's not like the coffee

trees want to have humans cutting bits of
them off and committing a holocaust of their
offspring.

Well, the trees, of course, don't want or
feel anything and originally evolved caffeine

for their own benefit. Caffeine is an insecticide
that effectively paralyzes or kills bugs chomping
on the tree.

Whether or not the insects go out experiencing
the greatest caffeine high ever is not known.

While caffeine is /technically/ lethal, it's
adapted for for 1g bugs, not monkeys 100,000

times more massive. So you'd really have to
try to win this Darwin Award.

But, if you must: to calculate the dose of
caffeine you'll need to ingest to have a 50%

of death, take your mass in kilograms and
multiply it by 150mg.

Or in terms of coffee, for every kilogram
of mass you have you need to drink one latte
to get a visit from the grim reaper.

That's a lot of coffee so it's not suprising
that there are no recored deaths in healthy

adults from this method and it's doubtful
that it's even possible. Because, while you're

busy getting the coffee in, your body is busy
getting it out by one way or another.

The rare recorded deaths from caffeine are
from diet pills, pep pills and crazy people
who eat the drug in its pure form.

Poison though caffeine is, you do still develop
addiction to the stuff. And it's is a real

physiological addiction not a wimpy psychological
addition like people claim for videos games
and the internet.

But caffeine isn't heroine -- rapid withdrawal
won't kill you -- it might make you cranky

and give you a wicked headache -- but since
caffeine releases dopamine to make you happy

and it gets rid of headaches there's really
no reason to ever stop using it.

And who would want to give up the stuff anyway?
I mean, aside from converts to Mormonism and

Rastafarianism. Caffeine is the world's most
used psychoactive drug -- and with good reason
it's pure awesome.

It increases concentration, decreases fatigue
and gives you better memory.

This isn't just a placebo -- these are real
effects replicable in a laboratory.

And, contrary to popular belief, drinking
coffee isn't a faustian bargain where the

devil gives you the ability to work faster
but in exchange makes your life shorter.

For normal, healthy humans there are no medical
concerns. Coffee and the caffeine within it

may even has medical benefits such as protection
from cardiovascular disease, diabetes and
Parkinson's.

Caffeine can even get rid of migraines, but
the amount required and the and method of
ingestion is... uncomfortable.
Moving right along...

You know what else you can thank caffeine
for? A little thing called the enlightenment.

In the 1600s people drank more beer and gin
than water. But with the introduction of coffee

and tea, people switched from a depressant
to a stimulant. It's not surprising then that

this time was an intellectual boon compared
to earlier centuries.

Ben Franklin and Edward Lloyd loved their
coffee for the same reason that modern workers

and students do. It's invaluable for staying
awake and concentrating when you need to finish

a TPS report or to get through that boring
physics class.

Coffee is the fuel of the modern world, so
go grab a cup guilt-free and get working smarter
and faster.

comments.text:
If you find a link to that paper that is free to read / download without 
signing up, send it to me. :)

But yeah, it definitely tends to differ from person to person. What's weird 
for me is that a few years ago, I would drink caffeine all the time in soda 
and tea and I actually never noticed hardly any stimulant effects from it. 
Even a cup of coffee I wouldn't notice, it would take 2 large cups of 
coffee to make me feel stimulated. Now that I don't drink it much I can 
feel stimulated just from a black tea, and a whole cup of coffee can be 
enough to give me pretty bad anxiety if I drink it too fast.

Was I addicted? I dunno, it didn't seem like it at the time but maybe. I 
just drank it without thinking about it much back before I knew much about 
how drugs affect the brain.
comments.author: Evan π

comments.text:
Uuuuhm, I actually don't know, after being searching for it... As I am a 
student, I get my articles through my university, so I actually don't 
know...
However, as much as I enjoy these discussions of the effects of caffeine, 
personal experience have to be overseen... Reading through the comment 
yield the ranging from being indifferent to the effects, to having such 
huge withdrawal synthoms, that they barely make it up in the morning 
without.

However, I find your hypothesis quite interesting, as it has been seen with 
other stimulants, that one gets a new "baseline".
E.g. is marijuana, where people with addictions tend to find the new 
baseline of calmness in the times, where they have got their stimulant. 
That goes without saying, that again, it tends to differ from person to 
person. :)

Overall, we do agree that the amount that comes in is the same, but gets 
handled differently, as an addiction grows.
However, as even the tendency of getting an addiction is different from 
person to person, this might also get quite tricky :/
comments.author: NotedAngellover

comments.text:
+NotedAngellover 
All I am trying to say is that while it technically does give you the same 
effect and you don't feel it, the reason you don't feel it would be because 
your baseline has become different in response, and so I think the OP for 
this comment was still right - that if you take it on a regular basis, you 
are getting the effect but your body has compensated for it in negatively. 
However I don't have any links to show that increased alertness and mental 
performance eventually return to normal if you take the same dose daily, 
but that's my hypothesis based on personal experience. I guess I can check 
out that paper, is there a place to read it for free?
comments.author: Evan π

comments.text:
+Evan π

While I grant you, that you do not feel the effects, you do still get the 
same effects...
The receptors do "prepare" the intake of caffeine of daily basis, and as 
you say, it yields withdrawal if not taken care of (Yeah, the 
downregulation).
Studies show that the uptake of caffeine is the same, even after longer 
periods after developing a tolerance of it. The difference lies in the 
metabolism rate.

So, to be short: One does still get the same effects, but might not feel 
it. The developing of tolerance increases the metabolism rate, in which 
"burns" the caffeine faster.

..

Check out the article: "Caffeine and the central nervous system: mechanisms 
of action, biochemical, metabolic and psychostimulant effects." by Astrid 
Nehlig, Jean-Luc Daval and Gérard Debry. :)
comments.author: NotedAngellover

comments.text:
+MangaEater68 
Well there is actually a chemical basis further than that. When you take a 
drug often and develop tolerance, it's more than just being so used to it 
that you don't notice its effects. Your brain actually downregulates the 
amount of receptors that the particular substance works on in an effort to 
maintain homeostasis... so you literally will not get as much of the same 
effects from it. And that is why you will get physical withdrawal symptoms 
as well (i.e the headache and fatigue).
comments.author: Evan π

comments.text: +sunyboy333 Which is why I simply consume more. *twitches. *eye pops out
comments.author: yakumo961

comments.text:
+sunyboy333 No, because it's still a natural antioxidant since it is 
derived from the coffee bean. Does spinach stop being high in Vitamin K 
just because you eat it every day? No. 
Also, adaptation doesn't work that way. You get into a hot tub, it feels 
hot initially, but over time, it goes from being super hot to feeling 
comfortable. Is this because the hot tub became less hot? Nope, the hot tub 
is the same temperature it was when you first got in. You just don't notice 
it anymore. 
Similarly, you might not notice that caffeine has traveled to your brain 
and is causing a chemical reaction, but does it mean that the caffeine 
isn't getting there? Nope, it's still getting there and working its magic, 
you're just not noticing it anymore because you're used to having that 
effect.
comments.author: MangaEater68

comments.text:
+sunyboy333 

No, why would it do so?
While one might not notice the caffeine boost from coffee or whatever, it 
still gets into the system, alongside whatever other chemicals that is 
released.
This means that no matter how long you're onto caffeine, you're still 
getting it into your system, thus having the benefits of it.

This is like any other ingested substance that one intakes. It will have 
the benefits, but one does not simply feel them.

comments.author: H enryuuki

comments.text:
"Of course, trees don't want or feel anything."

Woah, woah, woah. That's gonna need some form of citation or supporting 
evidence.

If you find it odd that a plant may feel and want like a people does, I 
refer you to the endless stream of people who still don't accept that the 
other animals want and feel. It took us this long to realise that our close 
relatives might share life experiences with us, it seems sensible to assume 
that it will take us much longer to figure out, to truly figure out, 
whether our more distant relatives - plants - can into the same feels but 
on a different level.

And by figure out I don't mean, 'well it just makes sense that they don't', 
because, well, history. History is full of people finding out that their 
hard held, 'logical' beliefs of the world are wrong. 'What makes sense' in 
a human mind has very little baring on what actually is in reality.﻿

comments.text: +Addison Kline One word…Illuminati
comments.author: Jeff Hill

comments.text:
Without caffeine, I'm sure coffee would be all about taste 
preference. While coffee may be an acquired taste, with or without the 
sugar and creams, it serves a purpose. Coffee gets you up and going and 
helps you get work done. Long-term coffee drinkers benefit from it. As the 
video said, it improves memory, concentration, decreases fatigue, and 
allows for lower risk for diseases. It would take a lot of coffee to 
actually give you problems. More benefits not stated in the video: coffee 
helps you burn fat, improves physical performance such as lifting weights, 
protects the liver, and can help fight depression. Caffeine may be 
addictive, but being addicted to it doesn't seem so harmful.

Oh, and if you're worried about stained teeth... brush them!﻿
comments.author: DeAngeline Sebastian

comments.text:
+Rebecca Campina Again, preference. Even a matter such as hot or cold 
coffee, or hot or cold tea depends on preference. Some people choose tea 
over coffee for the lower amount of calories, sugar, taste, ability to 
hydrate you more than coffee, etc. Tea is just another alternative for 
caffeine intake. It's healthy, but it doesn't necessarily put coffee down 
as not healthy as well. Tea performs an equal deal of health benefits that 
I previously mentioned and displayed in this video. There are just as many 
tea addicts as there are coffee addicts. The addictive property of the two 
is caffeine.
comments.author: DeAngeline Sebastian

comments.text:
+Samantha Catlett after an 8-12oz cup of coffee, a person has about 6 hours 
of simulant and energy to work with before they "crash". it's a person's 
responsibility to control their time management and maintain their health. 
still, as coffee may make them crazy, there are no major physical damages. 
people are uneducated about the effects of coffee/caffeine. there are 
(legal) alternatives to instant energy such as 5-hour energy drinks, 
caffeinated tea, supplements/pills... but coffee is the safest choice.
comments.author: DeAngeline Sebastian

comments.text:
+DeAngeline Sebastian A lot of people are commenting this video and 
claiming that tea is better. Is it really better? What benefits does coffee 
have that tea lacks?
comments.author: Rebecca Campina

comments.text:
+Rebecca Campina Caffeine is essentially tasteless. Coffee itself has a 
flavor of it's own. You would think a dark roast coffee would have more 
caffeine because it's stronger in flavor than light roast, but the content 
doesn't actually change much at all. Decaf has does not mean "no caffeine". 
There is a chemical process that takes out most of the caffeine in coffee, 
tea, and chocolate, but not completely. Coffee isn't for everyone but decaf 
comes with benefits for people with high blood sugar and tolerance issues. 
Decaf still stimulates you as regular coffee would, but lowers the risk of 
jitters/nervousness or irregular heartbeats. It's all about personal 
preference.
comments.author: DeAngeline Sebastian

comments.text:
+Rebecca Campina Caffeine itself is bitter but there is so little in 
contained in coffee that you can't taste it at all. What most people 
(myself included) hate (or love) about coffee is the aroma.

comments.text:
Mormons try to avoid any substance that can be too addictive, caffeine, 
alcohol, and other such 'drugs'. However it's not necessarily a part of the 
faith, although it could be considered part of the dogma. The code by witch 
they treat their bodies is called the 'Word of Wisdom' which basically just 
lists all the substances harmful to the human body. If you have an 
addiction, the church will offer aid in helping you move past your 
addiction. But so far as I know they don't care if you just drink 
coffee/alcohol so long as it does not form an addiction.
And they aren't set in stone, people are free to fiddle with the Word to 
their heart's content. For example one of the things listed is hot 
beverages, but everyone still drinks hot chocolate or broth XD﻿

comments.author: Cinestar Productions

comments.text:
I don't like coffee, it taste like bitter water. It is also addicting, and 
that's never a good thing - and ignore people that tell you otherwise, they 
are probably already addicted, and addicts are always saying the same 
thing. For all I know, in a long run, coffee is bad for health, especially 
if you drink too much of it. Of course too much of everything is bad for 
you, but guess what.. If you are addicted it's actually more likely that 
you'll start drinking more and more !﻿
comments.author: WMTeWu

comments.text:
+Evan π It is found naturally in the  leaves, seeds, and fruits of more 
than 60 plants. It's also found in medication because it relieves pain. 
Here's a list of just a few of the things you commonly consume that have 
caffeine in it, including:

Breakfast Cereals (11)
Baked Products (27)
Legumes and Legume Products (2)
Dairy and Egg Products (11)
Snacks (5)
Sweets (86)
Beverages (68)
Fast Foods, generic (5)
 
http://nutritiondata.self.com/foods-000131000000000000000.html
